title: The Greatest Show in the Galaxy
dialogue_triumphs: Nord: 'Get lost… or I'll do something 'orrible to your ears.'
Ace: 'You're just an ageing hippy, Professor.'
Bellboy, about to be killed by his creations: 'You were a wonderful clown once. Funny, inventive… I'm not helping you any more.'
goofs: Ace pins Flowerchild's earring to her jacket, although she was wearing it in 'Silver Nemesis'.

continuity_notes.name: Ace
continuity_notes.description: The Doctor's companion, who went to a circus as a child and found it boring except for the clowns.

continuity_notes.name: Gods of Ragnarok
continuity_notes.description: Powerful entities known to the Doctor, whom he claims to have fought 'all through time'.

continuity_notes.name: Captain Cook
continuity_notes.description: A galactic explorer who has visited numerous planets and has extensive knowledge of various alien worlds.

Bradbury's Something Wicked This Way Comes
links: Ace tries on the fourth Doctor's scarf and Mel's costume from 'Paradise Towers'.

locations.name: The Psychic Circus
locations.description: A mysterious circus on the planet Segonax, central to the story's events.

locations.name: Segonax
locations.description: The planet where the Psychic Circus is located.

additional_notes: The Doctor quotes Neil Armstrong ('One small step for man') and Al Jolson, via Bachman Turner Overdrive ('You ain't seen nothin' yet'). The story could be interpreted as a metaphor about the production of Doctor Who, with various characters representing different aspects of the show's production and fandom.
bottom_line: A return of chaos, magic and surrealism to Doctor Who, the story summed up by the scene in which the Doctor walks out of a confrontation amid carnage. Whizz Kid is a (not very subtle) parody of anally retentive, obsessive fans. The ideas in this, one of the most iconic stories, are very imaginative and the direction is psychedelic.
